p.s: The text includes a few informative, but mostly argumentative elements.
I would interpret the first two paragraphs as both informative and argumentative, since the author uses the given information to get his point across.
An example for that technique is using figures like Â£100mmillion (l. 1).
Another way to convince the reader of his opinion is the usage of stylistic devices in the second paragraph.
Mataphors like sit at the bottom of educational achievement (l. 7) are meant to make the situation in parallel societies clear.
You don't learn [...] if someone is holding you up is another example of metaphors in argumentative texts.
This one specifically is used to once again show the significance of trying to integrate.
The article is written in a very serious, perhaps even cold way, which is fitting for the serious message.
This can also be a way to convince the readers of your opinion, showing them that the topic is important and that change needs to happen.
In the last paragraph, the author states his most important argument, so it is the point the reader is more likely to remember.
Another communicative strategy he uses is using the word us (l. 23), which makes the reader feel included.
Ending an article that way makes it easier to convince somebody of your opinion.
